channel.title: Who vs. Whom; A lesson on grammar
channel.description:
Well apparently not so many of you are aware of when to use who vs whom in a sentence.
Who: Subject Whom: Indirect / Receiver / Observer
For example, if you're talking about someone performing an action, use who. If you're talking about someone receiving or being an observer to an action, use whom.
[b]Examples:[/b]
[s]"Whom are you talking to?"[/s] "To whom are you talking?" -- You are doing the talking, and someone else is receiving the action of talking. "Who is there?" -- Someone is there, performing the action of being. [s]"Whom did you give it to?"[/s] "To whom did you give it?" -- You are doing the giving, someone else is the receiver of the action. "To whom it may concern" -- [i]It[/i] is doing the concerning. "Who gave the gift to you?" -- Someone else was doing the giving. "Who killed him?" -- Someone was doing the killing. "The people who abused him were put in jail." -- [i]Him[/i] is the receiver of the action of abusing, which was performed by someone else.
